BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 11, 1919.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

LACROSSE PROSPECTS BRIGHT

DR. LATANE MADE NEW DEAN

JONES TO LEAD FOOTBALL TAEM

BOARD ELECTS BAKER TRUSTEE

Fourteen "H" Men back,including Capt.
"Herb" Baxley—Defense to be
Particularly Strong.

Head of History Department Succeeds
Dr. Brush as Dean of Faculty—Long
Associated with Hopkins.

All-Maryland Asterisk Chosen Captain
of 1919 Eleven—Banquet at Emerson Follows Theatre Party.

Secretary of War to Take Active Part
in University Affairs—Was Member of Famous Class of '92.

The prospects of the lacrosse
team for the coming season are
exceptionally bright. Since the
first practice, on December 14, the
squad has been steadily increasing
in size, as well as merit, and at
present boasts of fifty-five members. In fact it is the largest
squad that has ever represented
Hopkins in lacrosse. Quantity,
however, is the smallest of the outstanding characteristics, for after
all it is ability and teamwork
which counts. The fact that there
are fourteen "H" men back, with
a quantity of very promising material, gives an indication of our
prospects for this year.
Ever since the memorable 11th
of November, enthusiasts looked
ahead to the coming spring, and
on December 8 the organization
meeting was held. Candidates for
the team were addressed by such
well-known "old timers" as Coach
Raney Wolfe, Gerhardt Schmeisser, Dr. Abercrombie, Dr. Fred
Blanc, and "Father Bill" Schmeisser. From that time on, the team
has been settling down to hard
work to retain the championship
won last spring. At this meeting
Johnny Frisch was elected acting
captain of the team, to hold that
office until the return of Capt.
"Herb" Baxley, who was away in
the service.
The team has been greatly
strengthened by the return of
Captain Baxley,"Dutch" Schmidt,
captain of last year's championship team, Frank Morley, John
Stanley and Bobby Hoffman, all
of whom held commissions in different branches of the service.
Other "H" men back this year are:
Sam Silberstein, Defandorf, Stuart, Beall, Brennan Sadtler, Williams, Meyer and Frisch. Besides
these there are a number of Freshmen from Polytechnic, City College and other high schools, as
well as a score or more of secondstring men from last year's team.
The defense this year will be exceptionally good.
Sadtler, a
Sophomore of last year's team,
will be back at goal, with Meyer
and Morley as point and coverpoint. Schmidt will probably hold
down the first defense position,
while second and third defense
will be picked from Brennan,
Hoffman and Kennady. "Tiff"
Williams bids fair to retain his
old position at center.
The attack, on the other hand,
needs strengthening. "Dodo"
Frisch and "Reds" Beall will very

At a meeting of the Board of
Trustees of the Johns Hopkins
University on February 4, Dr.
John H.Latane,professor of American history, was elected dean of
the faculty, to succeed Dr. Murray P. Brush, who has resigned
to become president of the Tome
School. Dr. Latane will continue
his classes in history, in addition
to his new duties, which will not
be assumed until Dr. Brush's departure in March.
The new dean has been affiliated
with the University not only in
the capacity of professor, but also
as undergraduate and graduate
student, being a member of the
famous Class of 1892. In 1895 Dr.
Latane received his degree of
Doctor of Philosophy, after three
years of graduate work. He then
went to Randolph-Macon Woman's
College, as professor of history
and economics, where he remained
until 1902. He was appointed professor of history at Washington
and Lee University, and remained
there until the spring of 1913. In
this year he received the degree
of LL. D. at the University of Alabama. Since then he has been a
member of the faculty at this University, as head of the History
Department.
Not only is Dr. Latane well
known as teacher, but also as lecturer, author and authority on
American history. He has been
actively interested in all movements of a patriotic nature, and
has been a member of the Maryland League for National Defense
for several years. As chairman of
the Committee of Arrangements,
he presided over the meeting held
at the Lyric on Great Britain's
Day. Dr. Latane is one of the
most popular members of the University faculty, both with students
and other members of the faculty.

Elmer Jones, '21, Black and
Blue's stellar back, was elected
captain of next year's football
team at the annual football banquet, held this year at the Emerson Hotel, on the evening of Wednesday, February 5. Preceding the
dinner, a theatre party was given
at the Auditorium. The four lower
boxes were engaged and the squad
enjoyed seeing "Take It From Me."
At the dinner at the Emerson,
Cashell, the captain of the team
last year, acted as toastmaster and
called for speeches from members
of the squad. Nearly everyone
responded, and the men who intend to return to college next
year pledged their hearty support
to the new captain.
The new captain has been a star
backfield man on the team for
two seasons, and was formerly a
City College athlete of reputation.
Stanley, Carey, Schmidt and
Calkins, old Hopkins gridironers,
were the only guests of the squad.
Twenty-two men, including the
managing staff, attended the dinner.

Secretary of War Newton D.
Baker was elected on February 5
to the Board of Trustees of the
University. He succeeded the late
Francis M. Jencks. Mr. Baker is
an alumnus of Johns Hopkins,
having received his degree with
the Class of 1892, and having
taken a year of graduate work
here. His election brings the number of alumni on the Board up to
three, the others being John M.
Glenn and B. Howell Griswold, Jr.
The result of this selection will
be far reaching, for Mr. Baker,
despite his many official duties,
intends to take an active part in
the University's Councils.
The benefits accruing to Johns
Hopkins will, indeed, be manifold.
The relations between the University, the Alumni Council and all
alumni will be greatly strengthened. This fact was probably realized by the Board, and indicates
a desire on its part to recognize
more fully the active work of
alumni. Men of importance in
business and professional life all
over the country claim Hopkins as
their Alma Mater, and their awakened interest and activitiy, considered from a material viewpoint alone, should be very beneficial.
Alumni activities will now, represented as they are by three members of the Board, take on a new
meaning. Mr. Baker will, furthermore, strengthen the conviction
held to by the trustees, that the
faculty should decide the educational policy of the University,
without interference in any way
from the Board.
The Class of 1892, of which Mr.
Baker is a member, is the only one
which has kept its organization
unbroken since graduation. Among
Baltimoreans who were in it are:
Dr.,Whitehead, Dr. John H. Latane, professor of American history at Hopkins, and just llama!
dean to succeed Dr. Murray P,
Brush; W. Calvin Chesnut, Dr.
Thomas R. Brown, Dr. John R.
Abercrombie, Gustav Lurm an
Stewart, Leon Greenbaum, Hugh
J. Jewett, of Baltimore city and
Harford county; Dr. Harry Adler,
George Stewart("Stovey")Brown,
Rignal W.
Lester L.
Stevens, Redmond
Baldwin,C. Stewart
and Dr. Theodore W. Johnson,
professor of mathematics at the
Naval Academy.

Homewood Selected for Spring Meet.

PRINTERS

Johns Hopkins Press

That the annual field meet of
the South Atlantic Collegiate Athletic Association is to be held at
Homewood, May 9 and 10, was decided at the spring meeting of the
association, held at Richmond,
January 31. H. G. Evans, secretary-treasurer of the association,
and V. J. Wyckoff, manager of
track, were the representatives
from Johns Hopkins.
Delegates were present from the
various districts of the South Atlantic, and plans were discussed
for the enlargement of the scope
of the organization.
Approval was expressed for the
direction of baseball, football and
basketball by the association; this
will prove one of the features of
the new rules under consideration
by the Executive Committee. An
invitation was extended to the institutions of North Carolina to
become members of the association.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 11, 1919.

TO GIVE PSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS
Freshmen of Hopkins and Goucher to
be Victims of Army Intelligence
and Color Blindness Tests.

Dr. Knight Dunlap, professor of
experimental psychology, has formulated plans for giving all the
Freshmen in the University the
Jennings test for color blindness
and the Army Intelligence Test.
In past years, Dr. Dunlap has
found that about 5 per cent. of the
men in his psychology courses have
suffered from colorblindness; usually from "red and green" blindness, which makes these colors
appear as different shades of gray
or yellow. The victims of color
blindness do not know that they
are color blind unless they have
been told, because they never have
had the sensations of color which
the normal person has. The Jennings test, which Dr. Dunlap will
use, has been used extensively in
the army and navy and takes only
about three minutes per man.
All the Freshmen at Johns Hopkins and at some woman's college
will be put through this test for
several years to come, until several hundred or a few thousand
tests have been made. From these
tests the relative percentage of
color blindness among men and
women will be quite accurately determined. It is generally stated
that there are more color blind
men than women, but this statement is not based on any such
'thorough investigation as Dr.
Dunlap intends to make. The
color tests on this year's Freshmen are to begin sometime this
week.
The army intelligence test had
been ordered for all members of
the S. A. T. C., but was not be:
gun before the signing of the armistice, and consequently the order
was rescinded. This test will be
given sometime this month to all
the Freshmen at the same time.
Hours for the test will be arranged
and announced later.

DR. RANEY OVERSEAS DIRECTOR
Librarian's Report Tells of Mission
Abroad—May Again Visit Europe
in Interest of American
Library Association.

To Dr. M. Llewellyn Raney, Librarian of Johns Hopkins University, fell the distinction of serving the American forces, as the
Director of Overseas Service for
the American Library Association.
The Executive Board of the
American Library Association has
invited him to make a second trip
to Europe in the interest of the
importation program. Should he
decide to go this coming spring,
for the University authorities have
already assured him of another
leave of absence, Dr. Raney will
confine his visits chiefly to The
Hague and Rotterdam in Holland
and to Berne and Geneva in
Switzerland.
The following extract from the
tenth annual report on the library
to the President of the University
gives a resume of the commendable task he undertook during his
first journey to the American
front in Europe:
"To the Librarian there fell the
privilege of a journey on a double
mission to Europe as the sole official representative abroad of the
American Library Association. By
courtesy of the President and
Board of Trustees, and the kindly
consent of Dean M. P. Brush to
serve as acting Librarian, he was
absent from January 20 to May
25, spending some ten weeks in
France, visiting England twice
and Switzerland for a few days.
"The task was, first, to arrange
for library service to the American army and navy overseas; and,
second, to open the way to secure
useful enemy publications for universities, colleges and public institutions of approved character,
including a number of the Governmental departments.
"For the former purpose, the
Association had been accorded official status by the Commissions
on Training Camp Activities, and
to the traveler were given letters
of authorization and introduction
by the Secretaries of War and
Navy to General Pershing and
Vice-Admiral Sims, respectively.
In interviews he will not soon forget, immediate and hearty sanction was given to the plans which
had been worked out after arrival
in Europe, study of British methods and conference with allied organizations, and been presented by
appointment at their respective
headquarters in Chaumont and
London, while, despite its preciousness at the moment, special
tonnage was provided, including
that to serve our prisoners of war,
for whom some material was
bought in Geneva. To both commanders,grateful acknowledgment
is due for according the special
privilege of unrestricted passage
throughout the American war
zone, visitation of naval stations,
and a trip with the fleet at sea,

Balloon Shed to Be Used as Gym.

The spring athletic teams will
be practicing on the grounds at
Homewood as soon as the plans
for building a wooden running
track in the old balloon shed are
completed. Coach Murphy has received estimates on the construction, and, if the shed can be transferred by the War Department to
the University, it is hoped that
the track and inside oval will be
in use by the middle of this month.
As the plans call for a onesixteenth of a mile oval track, one
end will extend beyond the building, as will also the finish of the
100-yard straight-away. A room
has been fixed, near the showers in
the basement of the Mechanical
Engineering Building, for the
lockers, some of which will be
taken from the Howard street
cage.
Although a few of the 'athletic
teams of the northern universities
have been doing their winter
training out of doors for some
time, Hopkins will be the first
southern college to offer such advantages.
The size of the track squad has
been somewhat increased by the
Freshmen and Sophomores in
training for their dual track meet
on February 21, and it is expected
that many will then go out for the
'Varsity team.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

FEB. 11, 1919

An Important Change.

No more faithful service could
have been rendered Hopkins than
that of Dr. Brush, who, succeeding Dean Griffin, served two years
as acting dean and nearly two as
dean. His intention of resigning,
which he declared some time ago,
was a shock to the University.
To whom could we now go with
our difficulties of schedule and the
like? Who would hear us with
such sympathetic patience, and
give such sound advice? We could
hardly conceive of our University
without him; we had lost a warm
friend and counselor.
As a dean, Dr. Brush was ideal.
His faculty for quickly making
friends, his intimacy with the student body, his tireless interest in
their.welfare, his tolerance, generosity, and practicality made him
invaluable to the University. Besides the loss of a dean, Hopkins
has lost an eminent French scholar; his classes were even a source
of interest and inspiration. We
wish him the utmost success in his
work as president of Tome School.
In casting about for a new dean,
the University was particularly
fortunate in securing the services
of Dr. Latane. An authority on
many historical, economic and political questions, he has achieved
through his lectures -and writings
wide reputation. - However busy,

he has always found time to devote to student affairs; and this
interest, together with his perfect
fitness for the position, will make
him a dean of whom we may be
proud.
Dr. Latane's popularity with
both faculty and students is most
pronounced. He is one of the University figures that the Freshman
learns to know at entrance, and
admires more and more as maturer years bring true appreciation. The undergraduates' interest in him. was well evidenced by
the unusually large attendance at
the recent lunch-time Open Forum
lecture. It is certain that no
choice of dean could have been
more acceptable to the student
body.
Baker A Trustee.

Of great importance among the
University's many progressive
strides since S. A. T. C. demobilization, is the election of Newton
D. Baker to the Board of Trustees.
It is an innovation for a native
of a State other than Maryland
to be selected as a Hopkins trustee. This departure from custom
in the case of Mr. Baker will make
a broadening of the scope of Hopkins' activities throughout the
country. Our educational facilities and unique advantages to students, which have won us deserved
recognition abroad, should be even
more widely known and appreciated in this country; and the active participation• in Hopkins' affairs of such men as the Secretary
of War will do much toward this
end.
The acquisition of Mr. Baker
will, moreover, undoubtedly cement more firmly the relations
between the alumni and their
Alma Mater. He has always been
deeply interested in Johns Hopkins, ever since his graduation in
the Class of '92, which produced
many most loyal alumni, and his
subsequent year of graduate work;
and, through his influence, the interest of other Hopkins sons will
be awakened. It is certain that
his responsibility as trustee will
even increase his interest, and that
he will be an indefatigable worker
for Hopkins' progress.

FACULTY NOTES
Dr. Powell is not expected to be
back at the University as instructor in English until after
next year. Last summer Dr. Powell obtained his commission in the
Intelligence Department of the
army.
Dr. Caswell Grave has returned
to the University as associate professor of zoology. Dr. Grave had
been serving as a captain in the
Medical Officers' Reserve Corps.
Dr. Lovejoy has returned from
his Government service and will
begin lecturing on March 3. He is
offering two new graduate courses
in philosophy: 1, The "Romantic"
Ideal: its sources, elements and
some phases of its influence in
nineteenth century thought, taste
and politics • 2, Political Philosophy of the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries: Hobbes, Harrington, Locke, Sidney, Montesquieu, Rousseau and Bentham.
The time and places of meeting
will be announced later.
First Cotillion February 28th.

The Cotillion Board had its first
meeting on last Wednesday, the
most important features being the
election of officers and the fixing
of the date for the winter cotillion.
The new president is J. Kennady Vickers and the new secretarytreasurer is Fred Bresee. The
Board lost no time in coming to
an agreement on the date of the
first cotillion—Friday, February
28. Posters were arranged for and
programs discussed. The price
will probably be $2 per couple.
Not the least important thing
decided upon was the date of taking the picture of the Board for
the Hullabaloo.

FIRST ALDRED LECTURE GIVEN
Series of Engineering Lectures Starts—
Percy H. Thomas Discusses "Public
Service Electric Power Systems."

At the first of this year's series
of Aldred Lectures, given by the
Engineering Department, Mr. Percy H. Thomas consulting engineer, of New York city, spoke on
"Public Service Electric Power
Systems." He outlined to a large
audience the method of determining the price rates for various
classes of consumers, described a
number of the safety devices, and
told of many notable cases of short
circuits.
The smaller manufacturing concerns, said the speaker, are coming more and more to buy their
power instead of generating it, on
account of the advantages offered,
of reliability and lower cost. The
only concerns that find it cheaper
to make their own power are those
who need steam for heating purposes; they can use turbo-generators that only take 10 per cent.
of the heat in the steam for electric power.
Reliability is the greatest of the
measures of success, as a shutdown of a short time might involve the loss of thousands of dollars—many times the actual value
of the power lost. This is true in
a newspaper plant, for example,
or in a blast furnace, especially in
the latter, where the molten
charge solidifies and can only be
removed at enormous cost. All
plants must have sets of reserve
apparatus to guard against this.
The cost of -power to the consumer is based upon two factors.
The load factor, the ratio of the
average load to the greatest load,
arises from the fact that the consumption is not uniform, but
varies during the day and during
the year. Those who use current
steadily should be charged less
than those who use it in varying
quantities. The diversity factor,
the ratio of the total load for a
certain period to the total maximum loads of any group of consumers, arises from the fact that
one consumer may have a light
load when another has a maximum — then the consumer who
uses his power when the other
loads are light should have a
cheaper rate. This last factor is
what makes the single central
plant cheaper.
Another interesting point is the
reason for the relatively high cost
of power for domestic purposes.
This class of consumers uses a
small amount of power with an exceedingly great outlay for meters,
transformers,- distribution lines,
etc., which fact justifies the greater rates charged. Most people do
not realize this.
Other factors that help to keep
down the costs are use of powergenerating units, so as to keep the
various units up to their best efficiencies under varying loads, distribution to •certain consumers

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 11, 1919.
Terrible Thief Takes Telephone.

Can it be true? Alas, yes;
somebody has stolen the telephone
out of the booth near the Gilman
Hall postoffice. We heard the rumor Friday morning, but did not
believe it until it was confirmed
by John Myers, with his hand on
his heart. The telephone operator, next door, has purchased a
padlock for that door, to keep out
the curious who ask for particulars.
We asked several of the gentlemen around what they thought of
a Raffles that would perpetrate
such a deed. One pronounced
him as "d—m clever," another as
"low down," and two Freshmen
were rendered speechless with horror. The E. E. Juniors, when
asked, at first inclined to blame
the crime on the M. E.'s, who have
of late been none too scrupulous
in the gentle art of misappropriation. They declared the thief deserved credit for his originality,
but when asked how much, replied
that the said credit ought not to
be unlimited, as it was not an
unlimited phone.
The president has hired detectives to locate the phone, and,
what is more important, the cash
that was in the box (probably several hundred dollars). A reward
of one book of Taylor meal tickets has been offered for any student who uncovers a clue.
University Scholarships Awarded.

The Board of University Studies
awarded on January 8, 1919, University scholarships for the current year to the following graduate students: Edith A. Beck, Elmer R. Hoke, Charles E. Lanning,
Mary Mendenhall, Edgar A. Morgan, Ruth Norton, Bessie Noyes,
Lloyd H. Reyerson, and Flora D.
Sutton.
with high tension, and use of mechanical fuel-handling devices.
Some of the methods of protecting lines from destruction are
fuses, circuit breakers, choke coils
and lightning arresters. Trouble
is localized by varying the critical
loads according to the distances
from the station. Some of the
cases of short circuit are extremely dangerous; on high tension busbars a crowbar dropped across
them will be turned to gas by the
intense heat, and men are nearly
roasted to death. A short circuit
in a manhole caused the street to
be torn up to a radius of 12 feet,
as by a dynamite explosion. Transformers must be specially designed
with regard to possible short circircuits, making the frame-work
strong enough to withstand the
tendency of the coils to separate.
Public service companies; more
than any others, must look to the
future, and study the probable
growth of the different kinds of
demands. It takes three or more
years to plan, design, finance and
construct additional plants—and
no company wants to be unable to
supply the power that is demanded of it.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 11, 1919.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

LACROSSE PROSPECTS BRIGHT

DR. LATANE MADE NEW DEAN

JONES TO LEAD FOOTBALL TAEM

BOARD ELECTS BAKER TRUSTEE

Fourteen "H" Men back,including Capt.
"Herb" Baxley—Defense to be
Particularly Strong.

Head of History Department Succeeds
Dr. Brush as Dean of Faculty—Long
Associated with Hopkins.

All-Maryland Asterisk Chosen Captain
of 1919 Eleven—Banquet at Emerson Follows Theatre Party.

Secretary of War to Take Active Part
in University Affairs—Was Member of Famous Class of '92.

The prospects of the lacrosse
team for the coming season are
exceptionally bright. Since the
first practice, on December 14, the
squad has been steadily increasing
in size, as well as merit, and at
present boasts of fifty-five members. In fact it is the largest
squad that has ever represented
Hopkins in lacrosse. Quantity,
however, is the smallest of the outstanding characteristics, for after
all it is ability and teamwork
which counts. The fact that there
are fourteen "H" men back, with
a quantity of very promising material, gives an indication of our
prospects for this year.
Ever since the memorable 11th
of November, enthusiasts looked
ahead to the coming spring, and
on December 8 the organization
meeting was held. Candidates for
the team were addressed by such
well-known "old timers" as Coach
Raney Wolfe, Gerhardt Schmeisser, Dr. Abercrombie, Dr. Fred
Blanc, and "Father Bill" Schmeisser. From that time on, the team
has been settling down to hard
work to retain the championship
won last spring. At this meeting
Johnny Frisch was elected acting
captain of the team, to hold that
office until the return of Capt.
"Herb" Baxley, who was away in
the service.
The team has been greatly
strengthened by the return of
Captain Baxley,"Dutch" Schmidt,
captain of last year's championship team, Frank Morley, John
Stanley and Bobby Hoffman, all
of whom held commissions in different branches of the service.
Other "H" men back this year are:
Sam Silberstein, Defandorf, Stuart, Beall, Brennan Sadtler, Williams, Meyer and Frisch. Besides
these there are a number of Freshmen from Polytechnic, City College and other high schools, as
well as a score or more of secondstring men from last year's team.
The defense this year will be exceptionally good.
Sadtler, a
Sophomore of last year's team,
will be back at goal, with Meyer
and Morley as point and coverpoint. Schmidt will probably hold
down the first defense position,
while second and third defense
will be picked from Brennan,
Hoffman and Kennady. "Tiff"
Williams bids fair to retain his
old position at center.
The attack, on the other hand,
needs strengthening. "Dodo"
Frisch and "Reds" Beall will very

At a meeting of the Board of
Trustees of the Johns Hopkins
University on February 4, Dr.
John H.Latane,professor of American history, was elected dean of
the faculty, to succeed Dr. Murray P. Brush, who has resigned
to become president of the Tome
School. Dr. Latane will continue
his classes in history, in addition
to his new duties, which will not
be assumed until Dr. Brush's departure in March.
The new dean has been affiliated
with the University not only in
the capacity of professor, but also
as undergraduate and graduate
student, being a member of the
famous Class of 1892. In 1895 Dr.
Latane received his degree of
Doctor of Philosophy, after three
years of graduate work. He then
went to Randolph-Macon Woman's
College, as professor of history
and economics, where he remained
until 1902. He was appointed professor of history at Washington
and Lee University, and remained
there until the spring of 1913. In
this year he received the degree
of LL. D. at the University of Alabama. Since then he has been a
member of the faculty at this University, as head of the History
Department.
Not only is Dr. Latane well
known as teacher, but also as lecturer, author and authority on
American history. He has been
actively interested in all movements of a patriotic nature, and
has been a member of the Maryland League for National Defense
for several years. As chairman of
the Committee of Arrangements,
he presided over the meeting held
at the Lyric on Great Britain's
Day. Dr. Latane is one of the
most popular members of the University faculty, both with students
and other members of the faculty.

Elmer Jones, '21, Black and
Blue's stellar back, was elected
captain of next year's football
team at the annual football banquet, held this year at the Emerson Hotel, on the evening of Wednesday, February 5. Preceding the
dinner, a theatre party was given
at the Auditorium. The four lower
boxes were engaged and the squad
enjoyed seeing "Take It From Me."
At the dinner at the Emerson,
Cashell, the captain of the team
last year, acted as toastmaster and
called for speeches from members
of the squad. Nearly everyone
responded, and the men who intend to return to college next
year pledged their hearty support
to the new captain.
The new captain has been a star
backfield man on the team for
two seasons, and was formerly a
City College athlete of reputation.
Stanley, Carey, Schmidt and
Calkins, old Hopkins gridironers,
were the only guests of the squad.
Twenty-two men, including the
managing staff, attended the dinner.

Secretary of War Newton D.
Baker was elected on February 5
to the Board of Trustees of the
University. He succeeded the late
Francis M. Jencks. Mr. Baker is
an alumnus of Johns Hopkins,
having received his degree with
the Class of 1892, and having
taken a year of graduate work
here. His election brings the number of alumni on the Board up to
three, the others being John M.
Glenn and B. Howell Griswold, Jr.
The result of this selection will
be far reaching, for Mr. Baker,
despite his many official duties,
intends to take an active part in
the University's Councils.
The benefits accruing to Johns
Hopkins will, indeed, be manifold.
The relations between the University, the Alumni Council and all
alumni will be greatly strengthened. This fact was probably realized by the Board, and indicates
a desire on its part to recognize
more fully the active work of
alumni. Men of importance in
business and professional life all
over the country claim Hopkins as
their Alma Mater, and their awakened interest and activitiy, considered from a material viewpoint alone, should be very beneficial.
Alumni activities will now, represented as they are by three members of the Board, take on a new
meaning. Mr. Baker will, furthermore, strengthen the conviction
held to by the trustees, that the
faculty should decide the educational policy of the University,
without interference in any way
from the Board.
The Class of 1892, of which Mr.
Baker is a member, is the only one
which has kept its organization
unbroken since graduation. Among
Baltimoreans who were in it are:
Dr.,Whitehead, Dr. John H. Latane, professor of American history at Hopkins, and just llama!
dean to succeed Dr. Murray P,
Brush; W. Calvin Chesnut, Dr.
Thomas R. Brown, Dr. John R.
Abercrombie, Gustav Lurm an
Stewart, Leon Greenbaum, Hugh
J. Jewett, of Baltimore city and
Harford county; Dr. Harry Adler,
George Stewart("Stovey")Brown,
Rignal W.
Lester L.
Stevens, Redmond
Baldwin,C. Stewart
and Dr. Theodore W. Johnson,
professor of mathematics at the
Naval Academy.

Homewood Selected for Spring Meet.

Johns Hopkins Press

That the annual field meet of
the South Atlantic Collegiate Athletic Association is to be held at
Homewood, May 9 and 10, was decided at the spring meeting of the
association, held at Richmond,
January 31. H. G. Evans, secretary-treasurer of the association,
and V. J. Wyckoff, manager of
track, were the representatives
from Johns Hopkins.
Delegates were present from the
various districts of the South Atlantic, and plans were discussed
for the enlargement of the scope
of the organization.
Approval was expressed for the
direction of baseball, football and
basketball by the association; this
will prove one of the features of
the new rules under consideration
by the Executive Committee. An
invitation was extended to the institutions of North Carolina to
become members of the association.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 11, 1919.

TO GIVE PSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS
Freshmen of Hopkins and Goucher to
be Victims of Army Intelligence
and Color Blindness Tests.

Dr. Knight Dunlap, professor of
experimental psychology, has formulated plans for giving all the
Freshmen in the University the
Jennings test for color blindness
and the Army Intelligence Test.
In past years, Dr. Dunlap has
found that about 5 per cent. of the
men in his psychology courses have
suffered from colorblindness; usually from "red and green" blindness, which makes these colors
appear as different shades of gray
or yellow. The victims of color
blindness do not know that they
are color blind unless they have
been told, because they never have
had the sensations of color which
the normal person has. The Jennings test, which Dr. Dunlap will
use, has been used extensively in
the army and navy and takes only
about three minutes per man.
All the Freshmen at Johns Hopkins and at some woman's college
will be put through this test for
several years to come, until several hundred or a few thousand
tests have been made. From these
tests the relative percentage of
color blindness among men and
women will be quite accurately determined. It is generally stated
that there are more color blind
men than women, but this statement is not based on any such
'thorough investigation as Dr.
Dunlap intends to make. The
color tests on this year's Freshmen are to begin sometime this
week.
The army intelligence test had
been ordered for all members of
the S. A. T. C., but was not be:
gun before the signing of the armistice, and consequently the order
was rescinded. This test will be
given sometime this month to all
the Freshmen at the same time.
Hours for the test will be arranged
and announced later.

DR. RANEY OVERSEAS DIRECTOR
Librarian's Report Tells of Mission
Abroad—May Again Visit Europe
in Interest of American
Library Association.

To Dr. M. Llewellyn Raney, Librarian of Johns Hopkins University, fell the distinction of serving the American forces, as the
Director of Overseas Service for
the American Library Association.
The Executive Board of the
American Library Association has
invited him to make a second trip
to Europe in the interest of the
importation program. Should he
decide to go this coming spring,
for the University authorities have
already assured him of another
leave of absence, Dr. Raney will
confine his visits chiefly to The
Hague and Rotterdam in Holland
and to Berne and Geneva in
Switzerland.
The following extract from the
tenth annual report on the library
to the President of the University
gives a resume of the commendable task he undertook during his
first journey to the American
front in Europe:
"To the Librarian there fell the
privilege of a journey on a double
mission to Europe as the sole official representative abroad of the
American Library Association. By
courtesy of the President and
Board of Trustees, and the kindly
consent of Dean M. P. Brush to
serve as acting Librarian, he was
absent from January 20 to May
25, spending some ten weeks in
France, visiting England twice
and Switzerland for a few days.
"The task was, first, to arrange
for library service to the American army and navy overseas; and,
second, to open the way to secure
useful enemy publications for universities, colleges and public institutions of approved character,
including a number of the Governmental departments.
"For the former purpose, the
Association had been accorded official status by the Commissions
on Training Camp Activities, and
to the traveler were given letters
of authorization and introduction
by the Secretaries of War and
Navy to General Pershing and
Vice-Admiral Sims, respectively.
In interviews he will not soon forget, immediate and hearty sanction was given to the plans which
had been worked out after arrival
in Europe, study of British methods and conference with allied organizations, and been presented by
appointment at their respective
headquarters in Chaumont and
London, while, despite its preciousness at the moment, special
tonnage was provided, including
that to serve our prisoners of war,
for whom some material was
bought in Geneva. To both commanders,grateful acknowledgment
is due for according the special
privilege of unrestricted passage
throughout the American war
zone, visitation of naval stations,
and a trip with the fleet at sea,

Balloon Shed to Be Used as Gym.

The spring athletic teams will
be practicing on the grounds at
Homewood as soon as the plans
for building a wooden running
track in the old balloon shed are
completed. Coach Murphy has received estimates on the construction, and, if the shed can be transferred by the War Department to
the University, it is hoped that
the track and inside oval will be
in use by the middle of this month.
As the plans call for a onesixteenth of a mile oval track, one
end will extend beyond the building, as will also the finish of the
100-yard straight-away. A room
has been fixed, near the showers in
the basement of the Mechanical
Engineering Building, for the
lockers, some of which will be
taken from the Howard street
cage.
Although a few of the 'athletic
teams of the northern universities
have been doing their winter
training out of doors for some
time, Hopkins will be the first
southern college to offer such advantages.
The size of the track squad has
been somewhat increased by the
Freshmen and Sophomores in
training for their dual track meet
on February 21, and it is expected
that many will then go out for the
'Varsity team.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

FEB. 11, 1919

An Important Change.

No more faithful service could
have been rendered Hopkins than
that of Dr. Brush, who, succeeding Dean Griffin, served two years
as acting dean and nearly two as
dean. His intention of resigning,
which he declared some time ago,
was a shock to the University.
To whom could we now go with
our difficulties of schedule and the
like? Who would hear us with
such sympathetic patience, and
give such sound advice? We could
hardly conceive of our University
without him; we had lost a warm
friend and counselor.
As a dean, Dr. Brush was ideal.
His faculty for quickly making
friends, his intimacy with the student body, his tireless interest in
their.welfare, his tolerance, generosity, and practicality made him
invaluable to the University. Besides the loss of a dean, Hopkins
has lost an eminent French scholar; his classes were even a source
of interest and inspiration. We
wish him the utmost success in his
work as president of Tome School.
In casting about for a new dean,
the University was particularly
fortunate in securing the services
of Dr. Latane. An authority on
many historical, economic and political questions, he has achieved
through his lectures -and writings
wide reputation. - However busy,

he has always found time to devote to student affairs; and this
interest, together with his perfect
fitness for the position, will make
him a dean of whom we may be
proud.
Dr. Latane's popularity with
both faculty and students is most
pronounced. He is one of the University figures that the Freshman
learns to know at entrance, and
admires more and more as maturer years bring true appreciation. The undergraduates' interest in him. was well evidenced by
the unusually large attendance at
the recent lunch-time Open Forum
lecture. It is certain that no
choice of dean could have been
more acceptable to the student
body.
Baker A Trustee.

Of great importance among the
University's many progressive
strides since S. A. T. C. demobilization, is the election of Newton
D. Baker to the Board of Trustees.
It is an innovation for a native
of a State other than Maryland
to be selected as a Hopkins trustee. This departure from custom
in the case of Mr. Baker will make
a broadening of the scope of Hopkins' activities throughout the
country. Our educational facilities and unique advantages to students, which have won us deserved
recognition abroad, should be even
more widely known and appreciated in this country; and the active participation• in Hopkins' affairs of such men as the Secretary
of War will do much toward this
end.
The acquisition of Mr. Baker
will, moreover, undoubtedly cement more firmly the relations
between the alumni and their
Alma Mater. He has always been
deeply interested in Johns Hopkins, ever since his graduation in
the Class of '92, which produced
many most loyal alumni, and his
subsequent year of graduate work;
and, through his influence, the interest of other Hopkins sons will
be awakened. It is certain that
his responsibility as trustee will
even increase his interest, and that
he will be an indefatigable worker
for Hopkins' progress.

FACULTY NOTES
Dr. Powell is not expected to be
back at the University as instructor in English until after
next year. Last summer Dr. Powell obtained his commission in the
Intelligence Department of the
army.
Dr. Caswell Grave has returned
to the University as associate professor of zoology. Dr. Grave had
been serving as a captain in the
Medical Officers' Reserve Corps.
Dr. Lovejoy has returned from
his Government service and will
begin lecturing on March 3. He is
offering two new graduate courses
in philosophy: 1, The "Romantic"
Ideal: its sources, elements and
some phases of its influence in
nineteenth century thought, taste
and politics • 2, Political Philosophy of the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries: Hobbes, Harrington, Locke, Sidney, Montesquieu, Rousseau and Bentham.
The time and places of meeting
will be announced later.
First Cotillion February 28th.

The Cotillion Board had its first
meeting on last Wednesday, the
most important features being the
election of officers and the fixing
of the date for the winter cotillion.
The new president is J. Kennady Vickers and the new secretarytreasurer is Fred Bresee. The
Board lost no time in coming to
an agreement on the date of the
first cotillion—Friday, February
28. Posters were arranged for and
programs discussed. The price
will probably be $2 per couple.
Not the least important thing
decided upon was the date of taking the picture of the Board for
the Hullabaloo.

FIRST ALDRED LECTURE GIVEN
Series of Engineering Lectures Starts—
Percy H. Thomas Discusses "Public
Service Electric Power Systems."

At the first of this year's series
of Aldred Lectures, given by the
Engineering Department, Mr. Percy H. Thomas consulting engineer, of New York city, spoke on
"Public Service Electric Power
Systems." He outlined to a large
audience the method of determining the price rates for various
classes of consumers, described a
number of the safety devices, and
told of many notable cases of short
circuits.
The smaller manufacturing concerns, said the speaker, are coming more and more to buy their
power instead of generating it, on
account of the advantages offered,
of reliability and lower cost. The
only concerns that find it cheaper
to make their own power are those
who need steam for heating purposes; they can use turbo-generators that only take 10 per cent.
of the heat in the steam for electric power.
Reliability is the greatest of the
measures of success, as a shutdown of a short time might involve the loss of thousands of dollars—many times the actual value
of the power lost. This is true in
a newspaper plant, for example,
or in a blast furnace, especially in
the latter, where the molten
charge solidifies and can only be
removed at enormous cost. All
plants must have sets of reserve
apparatus to guard against this.
The cost of -power to the consumer is based upon two factors.
The load factor, the ratio of the
average load to the greatest load,
arises from the fact that the consumption is not uniform, but
varies during the day and during
the year. Those who use current
steadily should be charged less
than those who use it in varying
quantities. The diversity factor,
the ratio of the total load for a
certain period to the total maximum loads of any group of consumers, arises from the fact that
one consumer may have a light
load when another has a maximum — then the consumer who
uses his power when the other
loads are light should have a
cheaper rate. This last factor is
what makes the single central
plant cheaper.
Another interesting point is the
reason for the relatively high cost
of power for domestic purposes.
This class of consumers uses a
small amount of power with an exceedingly great outlay for meters,
transformers,- distribution lines,
etc., which fact justifies the greater rates charged. Most people do
not realize this.
Other factors that help to keep
down the costs are use of powergenerating units, so as to keep the
various units up to their best efficiencies under varying loads, distribution to •certain consumers

Terrible Thief Takes Telephone.

Can it be true? Alas, yes;
somebody has stolen the telephone
out of the booth near the Gilman
Hall postoffice. We heard the rumor Friday morning, but did not
believe it until it was confirmed
by John Myers, with his hand on
his heart. The telephone operator, next door, has purchased a
padlock for that door, to keep out
the curious who ask for particulars.
We asked several of the gentlemen around what they thought of
a Raffles that would perpetrate
such a deed. One pronounced
him as "d—m clever," another as
"low down," and two Freshmen
were rendered speechless with horror. The E. E. Juniors, when
asked, at first inclined to blame
the crime on the M. E.'s, who have
of late been none too scrupulous
in the gentle art of misappropriation. They declared the thief deserved credit for his originality,
but when asked how much, replied
that the said credit ought not to
be unlimited, as it was not an
unlimited phone.
The president has hired detectives to locate the phone, and,
what is more important, the cash
that was in the box (probably several hundred dollars). A reward
of one book of Taylor meal tickets has been offered for any student who uncovers a clue.
University Scholarships Awarded.

The Board of University Studies
awarded on January 8, 1919, University scholarships for the current year to the following graduate students: Edith A. Beck, Elmer R. Hoke, Charles E. Lanning,
Mary Mendenhall, Edgar A. Morgan, Ruth Norton, Bessie Noyes,
Lloyd H. Reyerson, and Flora D.
Sutton.
with high tension, and use of mechanical fuel-handling devices.
Some of the methods of protecting lines from destruction are
fuses, circuit breakers, choke coils
and lightning arresters. Trouble
is localized by varying the critical
loads according to the distances
from the station. Some of the
cases of short circuit are extremely dangerous; on high tension busbars a crowbar dropped across
them will be turned to gas by the
intense heat, and men are nearly
roasted to death. A short circuit
in a manhole caused the street to
be torn up to a radius of 12 feet,
as by a dynamite explosion. Transformers must be specially designed
with regard to possible short circircuits, making the frame-work
strong enough to withstand the
tendency of the coils to separate.
Public service companies; more
than any others, must look to the
future, and study the probable
growth of the different kinds of
demands. It takes three or more
years to plan, design, finance and
construct additional plants—and
no company wants to be unable to
supply the power that is demanded of it.
